welcome back ÿπÿØŸÜÿß ÿ®ÿπÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ∫Ÿäÿ®ÿ© üòÖ üöÄ Next Step: SWE.2 ‚Äì From Requirement to Architecture and Model! üöÄI‚Äôm thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy ‚Äì : SWE.2 ‚Äì Software Architecture Design! üöÄIn this stage, we‚Äôll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Here‚Äôs what to expect:1Ô∏è‚É£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:üîπMain State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.üîπCurrent Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.üîπSOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.üîπBalancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2Ô∏è‚É£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: üîπ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms ‚ûî MainSM, 100 ms ‚ûî LimitsCalc, 200 ms ‚ûî SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms ‚ûî Balancing) üîπ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks üîπ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as üîÑ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3Ô∏è‚É£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:üîπPrototype each core module and simulate their interactions.üîπAuto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.üîπRun Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4Ô∏è‚É£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:üîπMIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.üîπFull Requirements ‚Üî Architecture ‚Üî Test Case traceability matrices.üîπAutomated test-management reports to track coverage and results.üîç Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project ‚Äîit makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).üîó the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! üåçüîãhashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(n¬≤m) down from O(n¬≤m¬≤), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

ùóõùóÆùóªùó±ùóπùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóîùòÇùòÅùóµùó≤ùóªùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùó∂ùóª ùó†ùó∂ùó∞ùóøùóºùòÄùó≤ùóøùòÉùó∂ùó∞ùó≤ùòÄIn a microservices architecture, authentication plays a critical role in securing internal communication and enforcing access control.This diagram shows the authentication flow using an API Gateway (like Nginx). When a request is made (e.g., POST /api/products), the flow goes as follows:1. The API Gateway forwards the request to the Auth Service to validate the JWT.2. if valid, it responds with a 200 OK.3. The Gateway then delegates the request to the appropriate microservice (e.g., Product Catalog).4. Then service checks user permissions and performs the necessary action.This approach ensures that each service remains focused on its core responsibilities while the gateway handles routing and initial auth validation.hashtag#Microservices hashtag#Authentication hashtag#APIGateway hashtag#Security hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#backend hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp hashtag#nginx

For many developers, firmware is a given, constraints that must be obeyed in production software.¬†‚ÄúBare-Metal Embedded C Programming‚Äù ( Packt , 2025) by Israel Ninsaw Gbati demonstrates, at a fundamental level, how coding firmware by directly activating system microcontrollers should be merely another step in the production process.¬†¬†The book consists of 18 chapters, starting with the basics, then discussing timers and system peripherals, before briefly touching on power management.¬†I recommend this for any developer looking to extract the maximum performance from their coding. hashtag#baremetal hashtag#C hashtag#Software hashtag#firmware hashtag#Packt

Senior Developer - Salesforce Commerce/ Senior Salesforce Commerce DeveloperElizabeth, NJ - MUST BE ONSITE 3 DAYS A WEEKRemote 2 daysNo H1B,CPT,OPTLOCAL CANDIDATES REQUIRED-NO RELOCATION 4 YEARS OF SALESFORCE COMMERCE IS REQUIRED. Person must be a hands on developer with Apex experience and at least 4 years of SF Commerce experience. Must be a team player and have ability to interact with business users.¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†4+ years of experience with Salesforce Commerce Cloud preferably with some B2B experience This is a contract position 6-12 months with the possibility of extension. They want local candidates as they will need to be onsite in Elizabeth NJ three days a week and could work remote two days per week. Summary To provide high quality code solutions to meet ongoing needs in the implementation, enhancement and support of the company s Salesforce Commerce Cloud platform and primary point of contact in the development efforts on multiple Salesforce projects. If you‚Äôre new to drafting contracts, here are some tips that will help you avoid some costly mistakes.When it comes to writing contracts, clarity and conciseness rule the day. A poorly drafted contract can not only confuse the parties as to what is expected from whom, but it can also become a litigation quagmire if a later disagreement over the terms results in a lawsuit.Writing contracts and agreements require a meticulous approach. Begin with a clear title and an introduction that identifies the parties and purpose.Define key terms, specify obligations, and outline payment terms, if applicable. Include the contract‚Äôs duration, termination conditions, performance standards, and, when necessary, provisions for confidentiality and intellectual property.Clarify liability, indemnification, and the process for dispute resolution, specifying governing law and jurisdiction. Address how amendments will be made, include an entire agreement clause, and outline severability.Provide space for all parties‚Äô signatures and comply with any notary or witness requirements. Attach relevant documents and have legal counsel review them. Keep copies for reference. Customization is essential, and legal advice is recommended for complex contracts.

welcome back ÿπÿØŸÜÿß ÿ®ÿπÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ∫Ÿäÿ®ÿ© üòÖ üöÄ Next Step: SWE.2 ‚Äì From Requirement to Architecture and Model! üöÄI‚Äôm thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy ‚Äì : SWE.2 ‚Äì Software Architecture Design! üöÄIn this stage, we‚Äôll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Here‚Äôs what to expect:1Ô∏è‚É£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:üîπMain State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.üîπCurrent Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.üîπSOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.üîπBalancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2Ô∏è‚É£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: üîπ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms ‚ûî MainSM, 100 ms ‚ûî LimitsCalc, 200 ms ‚ûî SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms ‚ûî Balancing) üîπ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks üîπ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as üîÑ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3Ô∏è‚É£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:üîπPrototype each core module and simulate their interactions.üîπAuto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.üîπRun Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4Ô∏è‚É£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:üîπMIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.üîπFull Requirements ‚Üî Architecture ‚Üî Test Case traceability matrices.üîπAutomated test-management reports to track coverage and results.üîç Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project ‚Äîit makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).üîó the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! üåçüîãhashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(n¬≤m) down from O(n¬≤m¬≤), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

ùóõùóÆùóªùó±ùóπùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóîùòÇùòÅùóµùó≤ùóªùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùó∂ùóª ùó†ùó∂ùó∞ùóøùóºùòÄùó≤ùóøùòÉùó∂ùó∞ùó≤ùòÄIn a microservices architecture, authentication plays a critical role in securing internal communication and enforcing access control.This diagram shows the authentication flow using an API Gateway (like Nginx). When a request is made (e.g., POST /api/products), the flow goes as follows:1. The API Gateway forwards the request to the Auth Service to validate the JWT.2. if valid, it responds with a 200 OK.3. The Gateway then delegates the request to the appropriate microservice (e.g., Product Catalog).4. Then service checks user permissions and performs the necessary action.This approach ensures that each service remains focused on its core responsibilities while the gateway handles routing and initial auth validation.hashtag#Microservices hashtag#Authentication hashtag#APIGateway hashtag#Security hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#backend hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp hashtag#nginx

For many developers, firmware is a given, constraints that must be obeyed in production software.¬†‚ÄúBare-Metal Embedded C Programming‚Äù ( Packt , 2025) by Israel Ninsaw Gbati demonstrates, at a fundamental level, how coding firmware by directly activating system microcontrollers should be merely another step in the production process.¬†¬†The book consists of 18 chapters, starting with the basics, then discussing timers and system peripherals, before briefly touching on power management.¬†I recommend this for any developer looking to extract the maximum performance from their coding. hashtag#baremetal hashtag#C hashtag#Software hashtag#firmware hashtag#Packt

Senior Developer - Salesforce Commerce/ Senior Salesforce Commerce DeveloperElizabeth, NJ - MUST BE ONSITE 3 DAYS A WEEKRemote 2 daysNo H1B,CPT,OPTLOCAL CANDIDATES REQUIRED-NO RELOCATION 4 YEARS OF SALESFORCE COMMERCE IS REQUIRED. Person must be a hands on developer with Apex experience and at least 4 years of SF Commerce experience. Must be a team player and have ability to interact with business users.¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†4+ years of experience with Salesforce Commerce Cloud preferably with some B2B experience This is a contract position 6-12 months with the possibility of extension. They want local candidates as they will need to be onsite in Elizabeth NJ three days a week and could work remote two days per week. Summary To provide high quality code solutions to meet ongoing needs in the implementation, enhancement and support of the company s Salesforce Commerce Cloud platform and primary point of contact in the development efforts on multiple Salesforce projects. If you‚Äôre new to drafting contracts, here are some tips that will help you avoid some costly mistakes.When it comes to writing contracts, clarity and conciseness rule the day. A poorly drafted contract can not only confuse the parties as to what is expected from whom, but it can also become a litigation quagmire if a later disagreement over the terms results in a lawsuit.Writing contracts and agreements require a meticulous approach. Begin with a clear title and an introduction that identifies the parties and purpose.Define key terms, specify obligations, and outline payment terms, if applicable. Include the contract‚Äôs duration, termination conditions, performance standards, and, when necessary, provisions for confidentiality and intellectual property.Clarify liability, indemnification, and the process for dispute resolution, specifying governing law and jurisdiction. Address how amendments will be made, include an entire agreement clause, and outline severability.Provide space for all parties‚Äô signatures and comply with any notary or witness requirements. Attach relevant documents and have legal counsel review them. Keep copies for reference. Customization is essential, and legal advice is recommended for complex contracts.

Post Content:
welcome back ÿπÿØŸÜÿß ÿ®ÿπÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ∫Ÿäÿ®ÿ© üòÖ üöÄ Next Step: SWE.2 ‚Äì From Requirement to Architecture and Model! üöÄI‚Äôm thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy ‚Äì : SWE.2 ‚Äì Software Architecture Design! üöÄIn this stage, we‚Äôll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Here‚Äôs what to expect:1Ô∏è‚É£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:üîπMain State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.üîπCurrent Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.üîπSOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.üîπBalancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2Ô∏è‚É£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: üîπ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms ‚ûî MainSM, 100 ms ‚ûî LimitsCalc, 200 ms ‚ûî SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms ‚ûî Balancing) üîπ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks üîπ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as üîÑ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3Ô∏è‚É£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:üîπPrototype each core module and simulate their interactions.üîπAuto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.üîπRun Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4Ô∏è‚É£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:üîπMIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.üîπFull Requirements ‚Üî Architecture ‚Üî Test Case traceability matrices.üîπAutomated test-management reports to track coverage and results.üîç Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project ‚Äîit makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).üîó the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! üåçüîãhashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(n¬≤m) down from O(n¬≤m¬≤), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

When a request is made (e.g., POST /api/products), the flow goes as follows:1. The API Gateway forwards the request to the Auth Service to validate the JWT.2. if valid, it responds with a 200 OK.3. Java 24: More than an update ‚Äî a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.üöÄ Key Features in Java 24:‚úÖ JEP 447 ‚Äì Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.‚úÖ JEP 456 ‚Äì Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.‚úÖ JEP 459 ‚Äì String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation ‚Äî ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.‚úÖ JEP 460 ‚Äì Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks ‚Äî relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.‚úÖ JEP 462 ‚Äì Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos ‚Äî perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.üß± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24‚Äôs cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: üîπ Richer domain modeling without ceremony üîπ Easier testing and mocking of application ports üîπ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters üîπ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray‚òÅÔ∏è AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ‚úÖ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ‚úÖ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ‚úÖ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe‚Äôre not just writing code ‚Äî we‚Äôre building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? If you‚Äôre new to drafting contracts, here are some tips that will help you avoid some costly mistakes.When it comes to writing contracts, clarity and conciseness rule the day. A poorly drafted contract can not only confuse the parties as to what is expected from whom, but it can also become a litigation quagmire if a later disagreement over the terms results in a lawsuit.Writing contracts and agreements require a meticulous approach. Begin with a clear title and an introduction that identifies the parties and purpose.Define key terms, specify obligations, and outline payment terms, if applicable. Include the contract‚Äôs duration, termination conditions, performance standards, and, when necessary, provisions for confidentiality and intellectual property.Clarify liability, indemnification, and the process for dispute resolution, specifying governing law and jurisdiction. Address how amendments will be made, include an entire agreement clause, and outline severability.Provide space for all parties‚Äô signatures and comply with any notary or witness requirements. Attach relevant documents and have legal counsel review them. Keep copies for reference. Customization is essential, and legal advice is recommended for complex contracts.

Post Content:
welcome back ÿπÿØŸÜÿß ÿ®ÿπÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ∫Ÿäÿ®ÿ© üòÖ üöÄ Next Step: SWE.2 ‚Äì From Requirement to Architecture and Model! üöÄI‚Äôm thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy ‚Äì : SWE.2 ‚Äì Software Architecture Design! üöÄIn this stage, we‚Äôll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Here‚Äôs what to expect:1Ô∏è‚É£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:üîπMain State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.üîπCurrent Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.üîπSOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.üîπBalancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2Ô∏è‚É£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: üîπ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms ‚ûî MainSM, 100 ms ‚ûî LimitsCalc, 200 ms ‚ûî SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms ‚ûî Balancing) üîπ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks üîπ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as üîÑ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3Ô∏è‚É£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:üîπPrototype each core module and simulate their interactions.üîπAuto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.üîπRun Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4Ô∏è‚É£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:üîπMIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.üîπFull Requirements ‚Üî Architecture ‚Üî Test Case traceability matrices.üîπAutomated test-management reports to track coverage and results.üîç Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project ‚Äîit makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).üîó the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! üåçüîãhashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(n¬≤m) down from O(n¬≤m¬≤), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

When a request is made (e.g., POST /api/products), the flow goes as follows:1. The API Gateway forwards the request to the Auth Service to validate the JWT.2. if valid, it responds with a 200 OK.3. Java 24: More than an update ‚Äî a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.üöÄ Key Features in Java 24:‚úÖ JEP 447 ‚Äì Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.‚úÖ JEP 456 ‚Äì Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.‚úÖ JEP 459 ‚Äì String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation ‚Äî ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.‚úÖ JEP 460 ‚Äì Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks ‚Äî relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.‚úÖ JEP 462 ‚Äì Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos ‚Äî perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.üß± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24‚Äôs cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: üîπ Richer domain modeling without ceremony üîπ Easier testing and mocking of application ports üîπ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters üîπ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray‚òÅÔ∏è AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ‚úÖ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ‚úÖ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ‚úÖ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe‚Äôre not just writing code ‚Äî we‚Äôre building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What‚Äôs your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

If you‚Äôre new to drafting contracts, here are some tips that will help you avoid some costly mistakes.When it comes to writing contracts, clarity and conciseness rule the day. A poorly drafted contract can not only confuse the parties as to what is expected from whom, but it can also become a litigation quagmire if a later disagreement over the terms results in a lawsuit.Writing contracts and agreements require a meticulous approach. Begin with a clear title and an introduction that identifies the parties and purpose.Define key terms, specify obligations, and outline payment terms, if applicable. Include the contract‚Äôs duration, termination conditions, performance standards, and, when necessary, provisions for confidentiality and intellectual property.Clarify liability, indemnification, and the process for dispute resolution, specifying governing law and jurisdiction. Address how amendments will be made, include an entire agreement clause, and outline severability.Provide space for all parties‚Äô signatures and comply with any notary or witness requirements. Attach relevant documents and have legal counsel review them. Keep copies for reference. Customization is essential, and legal advice is recommended for complex contracts.

Post Content:
welcome back ÿπÿØŸÜÿß ÿ®ÿπÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ∫Ÿäÿ®ÿ© üòÖ üöÄ Next Step: SWE.2 ‚Äì From Requirement to Architecture and Model! üöÄI‚Äôm thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy ‚Äì : SWE.2 ‚Äì Software Architecture Design! üöÄIn this stage, we‚Äôll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Here‚Äôs what to expect:1Ô∏è‚É£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:üîπMain State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.üîπCurrent Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.üîπSOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.üîπBalancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2Ô∏è‚É£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: üîπ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms ‚ûî MainSM, 100 ms ‚ûî LimitsCalc, 200 ms ‚ûî SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms ‚ûî Balancing) üîπ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks üîπ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as üîÑ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3Ô∏è‚É£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:üîπPrototype each core module and simulate their interactions.üîπAuto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.üîπRun Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4Ô∏è‚É£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:üîπMIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.üîπFull Requirements ‚Üî Architecture ‚Üî Test Case traceability matrices.üîπAutomated test-management reports to track coverage and results.üîç Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project ‚Äîit makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).üîó the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! üåçüîãhashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

GCC15 is out, with prime path coverage! I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(n¬≤m) down from O(n¬≤m¬≤), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

When a request is made (e.g., POST /api/products), the flow goes as follows:1. The API Gateway forwards the request to the Auth Service to validate the JWT.2. if valid, it responds with a 200 OK.3. Java 24: More than an update ‚Äî a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.üöÄ Key Features in Java 24:‚úÖ JEP 447 ‚Äì Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.‚úÖ JEP 456 ‚Äì Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.‚úÖ JEP 459 ‚Äì String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation ‚Äî ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.‚úÖ JEP 460 ‚Äì Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks ‚Äî relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.‚úÖ JEP 462 ‚Äì Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos ‚Äî perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.üß± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24‚Äôs cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: üîπ Richer domain modeling without ceremony üîπ Easier testing and mocking of application ports üîπ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters üîπ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray‚òÅÔ∏è AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ‚úÖ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ‚úÖ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ‚úÖ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe‚Äôre not just writing code ‚Äî we‚Äôre building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What‚Äôs your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Why Rate Limiting is Critical in Backend Systems Have you ever thought about what happens if a single user keeps sending repeated requests to a backend server?It may seem harmless at first ‚Äî just one user refreshing the page. But in reality, this can lead to:üöß Unnecessary load on the serverüß† Poor resource utilizationüê¢ Increased response time for other users‚ùå System becoming inaccessible or even crashing in extreme casesThat's where Rate Limiting comes in.What is Rate Limiting?Rate Limiting is a technique used to control how many requests a user can make to the server within a specific time frame.It ensures:Fair usageProtection against abuseBetter server health & performanceIn most cases, we apply rate limiting based on the user‚Äôs IP address. For example:If a user hits the server more than 5 times in a short window (say 10 seconds), we either block the requests temporarily or slow them down.üß† My Approach: Redis-Based IP Rate LimitingHere's the flow I implemented:‚úÖ Accept incoming request from userüîç Check if user‚Äôs IP is in Redisüìà If present, get the current count:If count > limit (e.g., 5): ‚ùå Send 429 Too Many Requests responseElse: üîÑ Increment the countüÜï If not present:Set IP count to 1 with an expiry of 10 secondsüîÅ After 10 seconds, the counter auto-resets TTL

If you‚Äôre new to drafting contracts, here are some tips that will help you avoid some costly mistakes.When it comes to writing contracts, clarity and conciseness rule the day. A poorly drafted contract can not only confuse the parties as to what is expected from whom, but it can also become a litigation quagmire if a later disagreement over the terms results in a lawsuit.Writing contracts and agreements require a meticulous approach. Begin with a clear title and an introduction that identifies the parties and purpose.Define key terms, specify obligations, and outline payment terms, if applicable. Include the contract‚Äôs duration, termination conditions, performance standards, and, when necessary, provisions for confidentiality and intellectual property.Clarify liability, indemnification, and the process for dispute resolution, specifying governing law and jurisdiction. Address how amendments will be made, include an entire agreement clause, and outline severability.Provide space for all parties‚Äô signatures and comply with any notary or witness requirements. Attach relevant documents and have legal counsel review them. Keep copies for reference. Customization is essential, and legal advice is recommended for complex contracts.

Post Content:
welcome back ÿπÿØŸÜÿß ÿ®ÿπÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ∫Ÿäÿ®ÿ© üòÖ üöÄ Next Step: SWE.2 ‚Äì From Requirement to Architecture and Model! üöÄI‚Äôm thrilled to share the next phase of my MBD diploma project from OS-Academy ‚Äì : SWE.2 ‚Äì Software Architecture Design! üöÄIn this stage, we‚Äôll take the system requirements defined in SWE.1 and build a modular, maintainable architecture that steers implementation, testing, and future evolution.Here‚Äôs what to expect:1Ô∏è‚É£ Architectural Views Break the system into clear functional blocks and define their responsibilities:üîπMain State Machine Manages core logic and coordinates inter-module communication.üîπCurrent Limits Calculator Computes safe charge/discharge thresholds based on real-time data.üîπSOC & SOH Estimators Tracks battery state-of-charge and state-of-health.üîπBalancing Logic Ensures individual cell voltages stay synchronized.2Ô∏è‚É£ Interfaces & Data FlowsMap each domain into software modules/packages with precise contracts: üîπ Defined fixed-rate tasks(50 ms ‚ûî MainSM, 100 ms ‚ûî LimitsCalc, 200 ms ‚ûî SOC/SOH estimators, 250 ms ‚ûî Balancing) üîπ Route signals (voltage, temperature, current) via buses and ZOH blocks üîπ Store each signal in the Data Dictionary as üîÑ a MTP Signals: (ImportedExtern (inputs) - ExportedToFile (logging) - Localized (module-internal))3Ô∏è‚É£ Modeling & PrototypingLeverage MATLAB/Simulink & Stateflow to:üîπPrototype each core module and simulate their interactions.üîπAuto-generate architecture diagrams directly from models.üîπRun Model Advisor checks for MISRA C compliance, execution efficiency, and RAM usage.4Ô∏è‚É£ Verification AlignmentEmbed test hooks and traceability throughout:üîπMIL/SIL Test Harnesses for unit, integration, and system-level validation.üîπFull Requirements ‚Üî Architecture ‚Üî Test Case traceability matrices.üîπAutomated test-management reports to track coverage and results.üîç Why it matters A well-crafted software architecture is the backbone of a reliable project ‚Äîit makes implementation easier to develop, verify, and evolve. By nailing this SWE.2 step, we set ourselves up for smoother integration (SWE.3) and rigorous validation (SWE.4).üîó the GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dpww-PjNStay tuned for SWE.3, where we dive into detailed design and implementation, plus start exploring our battery and planetary models! üåçüîãhashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#MBD hashtag#VModel hashtag#SWE2 hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MATLABSimulink hashtag#BMS

I wrote a paper about the my implementation, the algorithm, and some new developments; notably, that prime path coverage subsumes MC/DC, and that using suffix trees for recording paths can eliminate redundant paths very quickly -- O(n¬≤m) down from O(n¬≤m¬≤), where n is the length of the longest path, and m is the number of paths. This is makes pruning redundant paths very quick as n tends to be small, and m tends to be very large.

Up until recently Amethyst Planner stored everything locally on the user's device. Unfortunately this meant that the user couldn't use the app across multiple devices (or easy switch to a new device).I was surprised to find there wasn't an existing plugin for sync'ing data between Hive and a backend API. We ended up creating TimestampedBox that wraps a Hive Box and provides all the timestamps to support the sync operation. What do you think? How have you approached synchronization and reconciliation across devices and backends?Checkout Amethyst Planner - the task app for hashtag#ADHDers the turns to-dos into dopamine.

Java 24: More than an update ‚Äî a powerful step forward for modern software architecture. hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBRWith the official release of Java 24, Oracle continues to evolve the platform in ways that directly support today's demands for scalability, modularity, and cloud-native design. For professionals like me who architect systems with Hexagonal Architecture (DDD) and deploy on AWS, this release brings substantial benefits.üöÄ Key Features in Java 24:‚úÖ JEP 447 ‚Äì Statements before super(...) Allows initialization logic before calling the superclass constructor. This enhances flexibility in rich domain models and simplifies base-class inheritance patterns in DDD.‚úÖ JEP 456 ‚Äì Unnamed Variables and Patterns (Preview) Reduces boilerplate when using pattern matching, making business logic cleaner and more expressive.‚úÖ JEP 459 ‚Äì String Templates (Second Preview) Provides safe and efficient string interpolation ‚Äî ideal for building dynamic responses, configurations, and messages without complex concatenation.‚úÖ JEP 460 ‚Äì Vector API (7th Incubator) Enables data-parallel operations for better performance in compute-heavy tasks ‚Äî relevant for analytics or event-driven systems.‚úÖ JEP 462 ‚Äì Structured Concurrency (Second Preview) Improves thread lifecycle management and simplifies parallel processing. This is huge for backend services needing concurrency without chaos ‚Äî perfect fit for services deployed via AWS Lambda, ECS, or EKS.üß± How this strengthens Hexagonal Architecture and DDDJava 24‚Äôs cleaner syntax and enhanced language constructs allow for: üîπ Richer domain modeling without ceremony üîπ Easier testing and mocking of application ports üîπ Clearer separation of concerns in inbound/outbound adapters üîπ Better observability and tracing when paired with AWS services like CloudWatch & X-Ray‚òÅÔ∏è AWS + Java 24 = Cloud-native powerCombined with AWS, Java 24 enables: ‚úÖ Lighter Lambda functions (faster cold starts with JDK optimizations) ‚úÖ Enhanced developer productivity with CodeWhisperer and Amazon Q Developer ‚úÖ Seamless integration with infrastructure-as-code (CDK, Terraform) and microservices ecosystemsWe‚Äôre not just writing code ‚Äî we‚Äôre building resilient, scalable ecosystems. Java 24 gives us sharper tools to do that smarter, faster, and cleaner.Are you already experimenting with Java 24? What‚Äôs your favorite improvement so far?hashtag#Java24 hashtag#HexagonalArchitecture hashtag#DDD hashtag#SoftwareArchitecture hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudNative hashtag#Innovation hashtag#BackendEngineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedInInsiderBR

Why Rate Limiting is Critical in Backend Systems Have you ever thought about what happens if a single user keeps sending repeated requests to a backend server?It may seem harmless at first ‚Äî just one user refreshing the page. But in reality, this can lead to:üöß Unnecessary load on the serverüß† Poor resource utilizationüê¢ Increased response time for other users‚ùå System becoming inaccessible or even crashing in extreme casesThat's where Rate Limiting comes in.What is Rate Limiting?Rate Limiting is a technique used to control how many requests a user can make to the server within a specific time frame.It ensures:Fair usageProtection against abuseBetter server health & performanceIn most cases, we apply rate limiting based on the user‚Äôs IP address. For example:If a user hits the server more than 5 times in a short window (say 10 seconds), we either block the requests temporarily or slow them down.üß† My Approach: Redis-Based IP Rate LimitingHere's the flow I implemented:‚úÖ Accept incoming request from userüîç Check if user‚Äôs IP is in Redisüìà If present, get the current count:If count > limit (e.g., 5): ‚ùå Send 429 Too Many Requests responseElse: üîÑ Increment the countüÜï If not present:Set IP count to 1 with an expiry of 10 secondsüîÅ After 10 seconds, the counter auto-resets TTL
